IdType="pubmed">37338426</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001284</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-83590-002</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37338425</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>22</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>22</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>7</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Eating healthy under work stress: A gene stress interaction model.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>425</StartPage><EndPage>434</EndPage><MedlinePgn>425-434</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001296</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Some employees tend to eat less healthy food when under work stress, while others tend to maintain a healthy diet. The factors underlying these different dietary choices are not yet clear. Individual differences in people's reactions to environmental stress may help explain this phenomenon. This study proposed a Gene &#xd7; Stress interaction model of dietary choice, suggesting that different dietary choices under stress may be related to DRD2 genes, which moderate the reward circuitry and have been associated with habitual use of alcohol, obesity, and eating behaviors.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">12,269 employees completed genotyping of their saliva samples and questionnaires on work stress, healthy dietary intentions, and healthy dietary behaviors. Nonlinear multiple regressions were used to test the hypothesized interaction of DRD2 genes and work stress on healthy dietary intentions and healthy dietary behaviors.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Individuals with higher work stress reported lower healthy dietary intentions, whereas healthy dietary behaviors exhibited an inverted U shape. DRD2 genes significantly moderated this relationship, and the above relationship was only detected among C allele carriers, whereas for the AA genotype, work stress was not associated with healthy dietary intentions or behaviors.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Healthy dietary intentions and healthy dietary behaviors showed different patterns of association with work stress. The DRD2 genes helped explain the individual differences in dietary choice under work stress. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Gan</LastName><ForeName>Yiqun</ForeName><Initials>Y</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Peking University, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Wang</LastName><ForeName>Lizhong</ForeName><Initials>L</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Shenzhen Zaozhidao Technology Co. Ltd., WeGene.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Schwarzer</LastName><ForeName>Ralf</ForeName><Initials>R</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Freie Universit&#xe4;t Berlin, Department of Psychology.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Chen</LastName><ForeName>Gang</ForeName><Initials>G</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Shenzhen Zaozhidao Technology Co. IdType="pubmed">37338425</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001296</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-83590-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="Publisher" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37307331</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>12</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jun</Month><Day>12</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Network of depressive symptoms before and after a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease.</ArticleTitle><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001292</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">A diagnosis of chronic kidney disease (CKD) may increase the risk for depression. The network perspective focuses on dynamic relationships among individual symptoms, which could advance our understanding of the development of depression during the transition to a diagnosis of CKD. The aim of this study was to use network analysis to examine the longitudinal associations of depressive symptoms from before to after a diagnosis of CKD.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">The analytic sample included 1,386 participants from the Chinese Health and Retirement Longitudinal Study. Participants were aged 45 years or older and reported a doctor's diagnosis of CKD in any wave of interviews between 2011 and 2018. Depressive symptoms were measured by the 10-item version of the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression. Cross-lagged panel network analysis was conducted to examine relationships between symptoms at three time points: prediagnosis; onset of diagnosis, and postdiagnosis).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">After controlling for other symptoms and covariates, feeling unable to get going and less happiness at prediagnosis were the most predictive of other symptoms at the diagnosis of CKD. Feeling effortful to do everything and depressed mood at the diagnosis of CKD were the most predictive of other symptoms at postdiagnosis.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Fatigue (i.e., feeling unable to get going, feeling effortful to do everything), less happiness, and depressed mood were central symptoms during the transition to a diagnosis of CKD. These findings highlight the benefits of identifying and managing these central symptoms to reduce the risk of activating other depressive symptoms. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Chen</LastName><ForeName>Jieling</ForeName><Initials>J</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0001-7728-3959</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>School of Nursing, Sun Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>8211523</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0278-6133</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo><CitationSubset>IM</CitationSubset></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>14</Hour><Minute>13</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>aheadofprint</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37307331</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001292</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-79582-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37307330</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>09</Month><Day>12</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>09</Month><Day>28</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>10</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Oct</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The differential predictive utility of two caregiver-targeted self-efficacy measures to promote oral health of underserved children.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>735</StartPage><EndPage>745</EndPage><MedlinePgn>735-745</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001308</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Oral health self-efficacy is a modifiable determinant of early childhood caries, which is one of the most prevalent childhood diseases. Yet, two common measures of self-efficacy (i.e., context-specific and behavior-specific) lack validation and clarity in the prediction of children's oral health behaviors. This study examined the psychometric properties of two caregiver oral health self-efficacy measures and investigated the predictive ability and age-varying effects of caregiver oral health self-efficacy on child oral health behaviors.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">In this secondary data analysis of caregiver-child dyads (<i>n</i> = 754, <i>M</i><sub>child age</sub> = 2.4, 56.2% Black or African American, 68.3% below poverty level), caregivers reported their oral health self-efficacy and their child's tooth brushing frequency, diet, and sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption at baseline and 4, 12, and 24 months. Psychometrics were examined with confirmatory factor analyses (CFAs) and the predictive ability and age-varying effects of caregiver self-efficacy on child oral health behaviors were examined with time-varying effect models (TVEMs).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">The context- and behavior-specific oral health self-efficacy CFA models indicated mixed model fit. In the predictive TVEM models, greater behavior-specific, but not context-, oral health self-efficacy predicted greater child tooth brushing across all ages. Greater context-specific oral health self-efficacy predicted healthier child diet throughout childhood, but greater behavior-specific self-efficacy only predicted healthier child diet in older children. Greater behavior-specific self-efficacy predicted lower SSB consumption throughout childhood while greater context-specific self-efficacy only predicted lower SSB consumption in younger children.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Both caregiver oral health self-efficacy measures were psychometrically comparable and differentially predicted oral health behaviors across varying childhood ages. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Hevel</LastName><ForeName>Derek J</ForeName><Initials>DJ</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-7703-3690</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Center for Behavioral Science Research, Boston University Henry M. Goldman School of Dental Medicine.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Henshaw</LastName><ForeName>Michelle</ForeName><Initials>M</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0003-2586-8466</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Office of Global &amp; Population Health, Boston University Henry M. Goldman School of Dental Medicine.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Endrighi</LastName><ForeName>Romano</ForeName><Initials>R</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-9272-5513</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Center for Behavioral Science Research, Boston University Henry M. Goldman School of Dental Medicine.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Adams</LastName><ForeName>William G</ForeName><Initials>WG</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-5330-0010</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Pediatrics, Boston Medical Center.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Heeren</LastName><ForeName>Timothy</ForeName><Initials>T</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0001-5643-3559</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Biostatistics, Boston University School of Public Health.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Jankowski</LastName><ForeName>Alexis</ForeName><Initials>A</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-9121-0008</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Center for Behavioral Science Research, Boston University Henry M. Goldman School of Dental Medicine.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Borrelli</LastName><ForeName>Belinda</ForeName><Initials>B</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-0859-796X</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Center for Behavioral Science Research, Boston University Henry M. Goldman School of Dental Medicine.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>UH3 DE025492</GrantID><Acronym>DE</Acronym><Agency>NIDCR NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList><ArticleDate DateType="Electronic"><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>12</Day></ArticleDate></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>Health Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>8211523</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0278-6133</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo><CitationSubset>IM</CitationSubset><MeshHeadingList><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D006801" MajorTopicYN="N">Humans</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D002675" MajorTopicYN="N">Child, Preschool</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D002648" MajorTopicYN="N">Child</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D020377" MajorTopicYN="Y">Self Efficacy</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D017028" MajorTopicYN="Y">Caregivers</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D009909" MajorTopicYN="N">Oral Health</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D004032" MajorTopicYN="N">Diet</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D011203" MajorTopicYN="N">Poverty</DescriptorName></MeshHeading></MeshHeadingList><OtherAbstract Type="Publisher" Language="spa"><AbstractText Label="OBJETIVO:">La autoeficacia en salud oral es un determinantew modificable de la Caries Infantil Temprana, que es una de las enfermedades infantiles m&#xe1;s prevalentes. Sin embargo, dos medidas comunes de autoeficacia (es decir, espec&#xed;ficas del contexto y espec&#xed;ficas del comportamiento) carecen de validaci&#xf3;n y claridad en la predicci&#xf3;n de los comportamientos de salud bucal de los ni&#xf1;os. Este estudio examin&#xf3; las propiedades psicom&#xe9;tricas de dos medidas de autoeficacia de salud bucal del cuidador e investig&#xf3; la capacidad predictiva y los efectos variables seg&#xfa;n la edad de la autoeficacia de salud bucal del cuidador en los comportamientos de salud bucal de los ni&#xf1;os.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="M&#xc9;TODOS:">En este an&#xe1;lisis de datos secundarios de d&#xed;adas de cuidador-ni&#xf1;o (n=754, Medad del ni&#xf1;o=2.4, 56.2 % negros o afroamericanos, 68.3 % &lt;nivel de pobreza), los cuidadores informaron sobre su autoeficacia en salud bucal y la frecuencia de cepillado de dientes de sus hijos, dieta y consumo de bebidas azucaradas (SSB por sus siglas en ingl&#xe9;s) al inicio y a los 4, 12 y 24 meses. La psicometr&#xed;a fue examinada con an&#xe1;lisis factoriales confirmatorios (CFA por sus siglas en ingl&#xe9;s) y la capacidad predictiva y los efectos variables seg&#xfa;n la edad de la autoeficacia del cuidador en los comportamientos de salud oral de los ni&#xf1;os se examinaron con Modelos de Efectos Variables en el Tiempo (TVEM por sus siglas en ingl&#xe9;s).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTADOS:">Los modelos CFA de autoeficacia en salud bucal espec&#xed;ficos del contexto y el comportamiento indicaron un ajuste mixto del modelo. En los modelos TVEM predictivos, una mayor autoeficacia en salud bucal espec&#xed;fica del comportamiento, pero no del contexto, predijo un mayor cepillado de dientes en los ni&#xf1;os en todas las edades. Una mayor autoeficacia en salud bucal espec&#xed;fica del contexto predijo una dieta infantil m&#xe1;s saludable durante la infancia, pero una mayor autoeficacia espec&#xed;fica del comportamiento solo predijo una dieta infantil m&#xe1;s saludable en ni&#xf1;os mayores. Una mayor autoeficacia espec&#xed;fica del comportamiento predijo un menor consumo de SSB durante la infancia, mientras que una mayor autoeficacia espec&#xed;fica del contexto solo predijo un menor consumo de SSB en los ni&#xf1;os m&#xe1;s peque&#xf1;os.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONES:">Ambas medidas de autoeficacia de la salud bucal del cuidador fueron psicom&#xe9;tricamente comparables y predijeron diferencialmente los comportamientos de salud bucal en diferentes edades infantiles.</AbstractText></OtherAbstract><CoiStatement>This study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (Identifier NCT03294590). Our work was funded by the National Institute for Dental and Craniofacial Research (Belinda Borrelli &amp; Michelle Henshaw, Co-PIs. UH3DE025492). The authors do not have any conflicts of interest to report.</CoiStatement></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pmc-release"><Year>2024</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>1</Day></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>41</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>12</Day><Hour>14</Hour><Minute>13</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37307330</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS1903651</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC10524688</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001308</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-79579-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Albino J, Tiwari T, Gansky SA, Henshaw MM, Barker JC, Brega AG, Gregorich SE, Heaton B, Batliner TS, Borrelli B, Geltman P, Kressin NR, Weintraub JA, Finlayson TL, Garcia RI, &amp; Early Childhood Caries Collaborating Centers. A Time-Varying Effect Model for Intensive Longitudinal Data. Psychological Methods, 17(1), 61&#x2013;77. 10.1037/a0025814</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/a0025814</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3288551</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">22103434</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Tiwari T, Mulvahill M, Wilson A, Rai N, &amp; Albino J (2018). Association between maternal acculturation and health beliefs related to oral health of Latino children. BMC Oral Health, 18(1), 67. 10.1186/s12903-018-0532-4</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1186/s12903-018-0532-4</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC5921390</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">29699555</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wilson AR, Mulvahill MJ, &amp; Tiwari T (2017). The Impact of Maternal Self-Efficacy and Oral Health Beliefs on Early Childhood Caries in Latino Children. Frontiers in Public Health, 5. https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpubh.2017.00228</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.3389/fpubh.2017.00228</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37261752</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>08</Month><Day>18</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>08</Month><Day>18</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>9</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>A randomized controlled trial of an information intervention to bolster COVID-19 vaccination intention among people with purity concerns.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>686</StartPage><EndPage>697</EndPage><MedlinePgn>686-697</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001295</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Previous literature has indicated a strong negative correlation between the moral foundation of purity/sanctity and vaccination rates. The current research investigated how purity concerns impact COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and tested an information intervention to bolster vaccination intention among people with purity concerns.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">Study 1 surveyed 566 Republicans and Republican-leaning Independents in the United States. Study 2 was a between-subject-designed survey experiment that investigated the impact of three statements on the COVID-19 vaccination attitudes and intentions of 637 Republicans and Republican-leaning Independents. Statement 1 argued that vaccines are not impure from a scientific perspective; Statement 2 made the same argument with quotes from the Bible; and Statement 3 was a control statement.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Study 1 established a significant correlation between the existence of vaccination history and purity as a moral foundation. Study 2 found that among those with no COVID-19 vaccination history, statements arguing that vaccines are not impure from either a scientific perspective or a religious perspective improved attitudes toward vaccination and intention to get vaccinated.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSION" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Purity concerns can be leveraged as a way to bolster vaccination rates, especially among conservatives. However, the impurity perception only mediated the causal relationship between the treatment and the attitude toward vaccines (but not the actual intention), suggesting that changes in the actual vaccination behavior are subject to factors other than purity concerns. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Factual</DescriptorName></MeshHeading></MeshHeadingList></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>8</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>43</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>13</Hour><Minute>10</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>11</Hour><Minute>24</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37261752</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001295</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-76328-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37261751</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>22</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>07</Month><Day>11</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>7</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Omega-3 fatty acids reduce depressive symptoms only among the socially stressed: A corollary of the social signal transduction theory of depression.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>448</StartPage><EndPage>459</EndPage><MedlinePgn>448-459</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001301</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">There is mixed evidence about whether omega-3 fatty acids reduce depressive symptoms. We previously reported that 4 months of omega-3 supplementation reduced inflammatory responsivity to a lab-based social stressor. In another study, we showed that those with exaggerated inflammatory responsivity to a social stressor had the greatest depressive symptom increases over time, especially if they experienced frequent social stress. Here we tested whether omega-3 supplementation reduced subthreshold depressive symptoms among those who experienced frequent social stress.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">Healthy, sedentary, generally overweight middle-aged and older adults (<i>N</i> = 138) were randomly assigned to 4 months of pill placebo (<i>n</i> = 46), 1.25 grams per day (g/d) omega-3 (<i>n</i> = 46), or 2.5 g/d omega-3 (<i>n</i> = 46). At a baseline visit and monthly follow-up visits, they reported depressive symptoms and had their blood drawn to assess plasma levels of omega-3 fatty acids. Participants completed the Trier Inventory of Chronic Stress at Visit 2 and the Test of Negative Social Exchange at Visit 3.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Among those who were overweight or obese, both doses of omega-3 reduced depressive symptoms only in the context of frequent hostile interactions and social tension, and 2.5 g/d of omega-3 lowered depressive symptoms among those with less social recognition or more performance pressure (<i>p</i>s &lt; .05). Findings were largely corroborated with plasma omega-3 fatty acids. No other social stress or work stress measure moderated omega-3 fatty acids' relationship with depressive symptoms (<i>p</i>s &gt; .05).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Omega-3 fatty acids' antidepressant effect may be most evident among those who experience frequent social stress, perhaps because omega-3 fatty acids reduce inflammatory reactivity to social stressors. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Madison</LastName><ForeName>Annelise A</ForeName><Initials>AA</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0001-6091-6844</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Institute for Behavioral Medicine Research, Ohio State University College of Language="spa"><AbstractText Label="N&#xda;MERO DE MANUSCRITO:">HEA-2022-0263R1</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="T&#xcd;TULO:">&#xc1;cido Graso Omega-3 reduce s&#xed;ntomas depresivos solo en grupos socialmente estresados: Un corolario de la teor&#xed;a de la transducci&#xf3;n de se&#xf1;ales sociales de la depresi&#xf3;n</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="OBJEVO:">Existe evidencia contradictoria acerca de si los &#xe1;cidos grasos omega-3 reducen s&#xed;ntomas depresivos. Anteriormente reportamos que cuatro meses de suplementaci&#xf3;n de omega-3 redujo la respuesta inflamatoria a un estresor social basado en el laboratorio. En otro estudio, mostramos que aquellos con una respuesta inflamatoria exagerada a un estresor social tuvieron los mayores aumentos de s&#xed;ntomas depresivos con el tiempo, especialmente si experimentaron estr&#xe9;s social frecuente. Aqu&#xed; probamos si la suplementaci&#xf3;n de omega-3 redujo los s&#xed;ntomas depresivos por debajo del umbral entre aquellos que experimentaron estr&#xe9;s social frecuentemente.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="M&#xc9;TODOS:">Adultos de edad media y/o mayores sanos, sedentarios, generalmente con sobrepeso (N=138) fueron asignados aleatoriamente a cuatro meses de placebo en p&#xed;ldoras (n=46), 1.25 gramos por d&#xed;a (g/d) de omega-3 (n=46), o 2.5 g/d de omega-3 (n=46). En la visita inicial y las visitas mensuales de seguimiento, informaron s&#xed;ntomas depresivos y se les extrajo sangre para evaluar los niveles plasm&#xe1;ticos de &#xe1;cidos grasos omega-3. Los parcipantes completaron el Inventario de Estr&#xe9;s Cr&#xf3;nico de Trier en la Visita 2 y la Prueba de Intercambio Social Negavo en la Visita 3.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTADOS:">Entre los que ten&#xed;an sobrepeso u obesidad, ambas dosis de omega-3 redujeron s&#xed;ntomas depresivos s&#xf3;lo en el contexto de frecuentes interacciones hostiles y tensi&#xf3;n social, y 2.5 g/d de omega-3 redujeron los s&#xed;ntomas depresivos entre aquellos con menos reconocimiento social (ps&lt;.05). Los hallazgos fueron corroborados en gran medida con &#xe1;cidos grasos omega-3 en plasma. Ning&#xfa;n otro estr&#xe9;s social o estr&#xe9;s laboral mide la relaci&#xf3;n moderada entre &#xe1;cidos grasos de omega-3 y s&#xed;ntomas depresivos (ps&gt;.05).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONES:">El efecto antidepresivo de los &#xe1;cidos grasos omega-3 puede ser m&#xe1;s evidente entre aquellos que experimentan estr&#xe9;s social frecuentemente, quiz&#xe1;s porque los &#xe1;cidos grasos omega-3 reducen la reactividad inflamatoria a los estresores sociales.</AbstractText></OtherAbstract><CoiStatement>All authors report no conflicts of interest.</CoiStatement></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pmc-release"><Year>2024</Year><Month>7</Month><Day>1</Day></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>22</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>42</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>13</Hour><Minute>9</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>11</Hour><Minute>24</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37261751</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS1902731</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC10330456</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001301</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-76329-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Appleton KM, Voyias PD, Sallis HM, Dawson S, Ness AR, Churchill R, &amp; Perry R (2021). American Journal of Epidemiology, 106(3), 203&#x2013;214.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">900119</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zeger SL, &amp; Liang K-Y (1986). Longitudinal data analysis for discrete and continuous outcomes. Biometrics, 121&#x2013;130.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3719049</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37261750</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>09</Month><Day>12</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>09</Month><Day>12</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>10</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Oct</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Risk and protective factors in predicting pediatric acute postsurgical pain: A systematic review and meta-analysis.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>723</StartPage><EndPage>734</EndPage><MedlinePgn>723-734</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001293</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Acute postsurgical pain (APSP), defined as pain within 3 months after surgery, is reported in most surgical pediatric patients, and a significant number of patients experience pain interfering with their daily life activities. We aimed to identify perioperative and psychosocial factors associated with APSP severity in pediatric patients undergoing surgery.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Web of Science, and CENTRAL were searched from database inception to October 2021. Studies that reported an association between risk or protective factors and acute pain in children were included. The primary outcome was the magnitude of association between identified factors and APSP, as measured by standardized effect sizes.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Thirty-eight studies (7,936 participants aged 1-18 years) were included. Meta-analysis of 12 studies (1,192 participants) revealed child preoperative pain, pain immediately after surgery, anticipated pain, temperament, pain catastrophizing, age, preoperative anxiety, parent pain catastrophizing, and parent preoperative anxiety were positively associated with APSP. Child pain coping efficacy was protective against APSP. We identified several modifiable child and parent psychosocial factors as predictors of APSP severity.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSION" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Given the small degree of association between identified factors and postsurgical pain, there is value in pursuing other factors that may better explain the variability in pain. Recognizing patients at risk for moderate to severe APSP enables early implementation of interventions to minimize pain burden. Interventions to enhance coping, an adaptive characteristic, may also help to reduce APSP. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Chow</LastName><ForeName>Cheryl H T</ForeName><Initials>CHT</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-4395-685X</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, Neuroscience &amp; Behaviour, McMaster University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Yu</LastName><ForeName>Christy</ForeName><Initials>C</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-5581-9078</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Bachelor of Health Sciences Program, McMaster University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Yu</LastName><ForeName>Wei</ForeName><Initials>W</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Bachelor of Health Sciences Program, McMaster University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Yeung</LastName><ForeName>Klement</ForeName><Initials>K</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Michael G. Version="1">37253209</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>30</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>30</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>7</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Responses to a COVID-19 vaccination intervention: Qualitative analysis of 17K unsolicited SMS replies.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>496</StartPage><EndPage>509</EndPage><MedlinePgn>496-509</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001297</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="UNLABELLED">The development of effective interventions for COVID-19 vaccination has proven challenging given the unique and evolving determinants of that behavior. A tailored intervention to drive vaccination uptake through machine learning-enabled personalization of behavior change messages unexpectedly yielded a high volume of real-time short message service (SMS) feedback from recipients. A qualitative analysis of those replies contributes to a better understanding of the barriers to COVID-19 vaccination and demographic variations in determinants, supporting design improvements for vaccination interventions.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">The purpose of this study was to examine unsolicited replies to a text message intervention for COVID-19 vaccination to understand the types of barriers experienced and any relationships between recipient demographics, intervention content, and reply type.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">We categorized SMS replies into 22 overall themes. Interrater agreement was very good (all &#x3ba;<sub>pooled</sub> &gt; 0.62). Chi-square analyses were used to understand demographic variations in reply types and which messaging types were most related to reply types.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">In total, 10,948 people receiving intervention text messages sent 17,090 replies. Most frequent reply types were "already vaccinated" (31.1%), attempts to unsubscribe (25.4%), and "will not get vaccinated" (12.7%). Within "already vaccinated" and "will not get vaccinated" replies, significant differences were observed in the demographics of those replying against expected base rates, all <i>p</i> &gt; .001. Of those stating they would not vaccinate, 34% of the replies involved mis-/disinformation, suggesting that a determinant of vaccination involves nonvalidated COVID-19 beliefs.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Insights from unsolicited replies can enhance our ability to identify appropriate intervention techniques to influence COVID-19 vaccination behaviors. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Blazek</LastName><ForeName>Eva control</QualifierName></MeshHeading></MeshHeadingList></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>22</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>42</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>30</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>16</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>30</Day><Hour>15</Hour><Minute>53</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37253209</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001297</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-75617-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37227880</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>29</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>29</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>6</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jun</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Physical Activity Regulation Scale: Development and validity testing.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>378</StartPage><EndPage>387</EndPage><MedlinePgn>378-387</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001283</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Behavioral regulation tactics used to manage actions after the formation of a physical activity (PA) intention are common to many theories, yet comprehensive measures of PA regulation are scant.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="PURPOSE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">To develop a reliable instrument of PA regulation and test predictive validity and its capacity to mediate the intention-PA relationship.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">To achieve a pool of candidate items, we used the behavior change technique taxonomy as a template, followed by a critical literature review of PA regulation measures to extract exemplar items, and then concluded with a Delphi feedback method (<i>N</i> = 4). The main study included a sample representative of the Canadian adult population to explore and then confirm the construct and discriminant validity, and internal consistency reliability of the measure using two independent samples (<i>N</i> = 683 and <i>N</i> = 727). Finally, using a 2-week prospective design, the full sample was used to investigate test-retest reliability, and predictive validity of self-reported PA at Time 2.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses resulted in a reliable 14-item, four-factor measure (internal consistencies &gt; .80) of (a) proactive regulation, (b) reactive regulation, (c) social monitoring, and (d) self-monitoring, we named the Physical Activity Regulation Scale (PARS). The PARS factors explained 18% of PA at Time 2, and mediated the relationship between intention and PA.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSION" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">While continued testing is needed, the initial evidence is supportive that the PARS may be a useful PA behavioral regulation measure to include for use within various theoretical models applied to understand PA. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Rhodes</LastName><ForeName>Ryan E</ForeName><Initials>RE</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0003-0940-9040</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Behavioural Medicine Laboratory, School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education, University of Victoria.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Lithopoulos</LastName><ForeName>Alexander</ForeName><Initials>A</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Behavioural Medicine Laboratory, School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education, University of Victoria.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016454">Review</PublicationType><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>Health Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>8211523</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0278-6133</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo><CitationSubset>IM</CitationSubset><MeshHeadingList><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D000328" MajorTopicYN="N">Adult</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D006801" MajorTopicYN="N">Humans</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D015203" MajorTopicYN="N">Reproducibility of Results</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D002170" MajorTopicYN="N" Type="Geographic">Canada</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D015444" MajorTopicYN="Y">Exercise</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D057566" MajorTopicYN="N">Self Report</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D005163" MajorTopicYN="N">Factor Analysis, Statistical</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D011795" MajorTopicYN="N">Surveys and Questionnaires</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D011594" MajorTopicYN="N">Psychometrics</DescriptorName></MeshHeading></MeshHeadingList></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>29</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>41</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>25</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>25</Day><Hour>12</Hour><Minute>45</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37227880</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001283</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-76042-002</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37227879</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>29</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>07</Month><Day>27</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>6</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jun</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Psychological resources and incident hypertension in the coronary artery risk development in young adults (CARDIA) study.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>368</StartPage><EndPage>377</EndPage><MedlinePgn>368-377</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001291</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Examining factors that may protect against the development of hypertension is critical, as hypertension is a major public health concern. We examined the individual and combined associations of psychological resources (optimism and mastery) on incident hypertension over 15 years.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">We used data from four exams of the Coronary Artery Risk Development in Young Adults (CARDIA) study over 15 years (CARDIA exam years 15-30). Optimism and mastery were standardized to a z-score separately and summed to generate a psychological resources score. We examined the incidence of hypertension (stages 1 and 2; systolic blood pressure [SBP] &#x2265; 130 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] &#x2265; 80 mmHg) and stage 2 hypertension (SBP &#x2265; 140 mmHg or DBP &#x2265; 90 mmHg) among participants without hypertension at baseline. Multivariable logistic regressions adjusted for sociodemographic factors, behavioral factors, and depressive symptoms.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Of 2,927 participants, 58% were women, 42% were Black, and the average age at the study baseline was 40 years (3.63). A higher psychological resources score was associated with lower odds of developing hypertension (stages 1 and 2; odds ratio [OR]: 0.89, 95% CI [-0.21, -0.03], <i>p</i> &lt; .01) and stage 2 hypertension (OR: 0.88, [-0.21, -0.04], <i>p</i> &lt; .01), after adjustment for sociodemographic factors. However, following adjustment for behavioral factors and depressive symptoms, the associations for hypertension (stages 1 and 2) and stage 2 hypertension were no longer statistically significant.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Greater psychological resources are associated with lower odds of hypertension. Associations were attenuated after additional adjustment for behavioral factors, indicating these factors may be important confounders or mediators. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Adamowicz</LastName><ForeName>Jenna Health-related quality of life and hypertension: a systematic review and meta-analysis of observational studies. Journal of Hypertension, 29(2), 179&#x2013;188. doi: 10.1097/HJH.0b013e328340d76f</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1097/HJH.0b013e328340d76f</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21045726</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Trudel-Fitzgerald C, Boehm JK, Kivimaki M, &amp; Kubzansky LD (2014). Taking the tension out of hypertension: a prospective study of psychological well-being and hypertension. Journal of Hypertension, 32(6), 1222. doi: 10.1097/HJH.0000000000000175</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1097/HJH.0000000000000175</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC5010231</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">24786293</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Virani SS, Alonso A, Aparicio HJ, Benjamin EJ, Bittencourt MS, Callaway CW, Carson AP, Chamberlain AM, Cheng S, &amp; Delling FN (2021). Heart disease and stroke statistics&#x2014;2021 update: a report from the American Heart Association. Circulation, 143(8), e254&#x2013;e743. doi: 10.1161/CIR.0000000000000950</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1161/CIR.0000000000000950</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">33501848</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Whelton PK, Carey RM, Aronow WS, Casey DE, Collins KJ, Dennison Himmelfarb C, DePalma SM, Gidding S, Jamerson KA, &amp; Jones DW (2018). 2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA guideline for the prevention, detection, evaluation, and management of high blood pressure in adults: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines. Journal of the American College of Cardiology, 71(19), e127-e248. doi:10.1016/j.jacc.2017.11.006</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jacc.2017.11.006</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">29146535</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Yano Y, Reis JP, Colangelo LA, Shimbo D, Viera AJ, Allen NB, Gidding SS, Bress AP, Greenland P, &amp; Muntner P. (2018). Association of blood pressure classification in young adults using the 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association blood pressure guideline with cardiovascular events later in life. Journal of American Medical Associaiton, 320(17), 1774&#x2013;1782. doi:10.1001/jama.2018.13551</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1001/jama.2018.13551</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC6248102</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">30398601</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="Publisher" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37227824</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>09</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>May</Month><Day>25</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Sociocultural influences on alcohol expectancies in early adolescence: Findings from the ABCD study.</ArticleTitle><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001290</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Alcohol expectancies (AE) during early adolescence predict early alcohol use initiation and problem drinking both cross-sectionally and prospectively well into adulthood. Yet, our understanding of the sociocultural factors associated with AE during this development period remains limited. This study examines associations between AE and sociocultural factors across various domains (i.e., individual, family, peer, school, community, and culture) in a demographically diverse sample of 10- to 14-year-old youth in the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development Study (ABCD Study).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">This cross-sectional study used 2-year follow-up data from the ABCD Release 3.0 for <i>N</i> = 5,322 early adolescents (<i>M</i><sub>age</sub> = 12 years [<i>SD</i> = 0.6]; 47% male). Approximately 60% identified as non-Hispanic/Latinx White, 17% as Hispanic/Latinx, 11% as non-Hispanic/Latinx Black, 2% as non-Hispanic/Latinx Asian, and 11% as mixed/other race-ethnicity. Separate models for positive and negative AE outcomes were conducted using linear mixed-effect models while controlling for demographic covariates.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Positive AE were most strongly associated with familism, followed by other peer, school, community, and cultural level factors. Negative AE were most strongly associated with the peer-level factor of relational victimization and the individual-level factor of negative life events, followed by other peer, school, and community-level factors.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSION" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">The present findings reveal the potential constellation of sociocultural factors that may serve as targets for modifying AE during the middle school years. Study results also underscore the need for future research that integrates cultural factors into our understanding of alcohol use risk and resilience during early adolescence. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>8211523</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0278-6133</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo><CitationSubset>IM</CitationSubset></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>25</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate IdType="pubmed">37227824</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001290</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-75206-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Curated"><PMID Version="1">37227823</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>06</Month><Day>22</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>07</Month><Day>11</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>7</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Implementing barbershop-based health-promotion interventions for Black men: A systematic scoping review.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>435</StartPage><EndPage>447</EndPage><MedlinePgn>435-447</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001294</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Health-promotion efforts among Black men in the United States have been limited in their ability to recruit, retain, and produce meaningful health-related changes. These difficulties have led to Black men being referred to as a "hard-to-reach" population-a designation that places undue blame on these men as opposed to the dissemination and implementation strategies being used by health-promotion specialists. Gender- and race-based strategies that align with the lived experiences of these men are likely to circumvent these challenges. Barbershops are cultural institutions that are uniquely positioned to promote health among Black men. There is little guidance on how to develop, implement, and evaluate barbershop-based efforts. This scoping review seeks to provide this guidance by applying the RE-AIM framework to analyze existing interventions.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">Information was identified by searching the following bibliographic databases: PubMed, EMBASE PsycINFO, CINAHL, and Web of Science. A grey literature search was conducted using Web of Science and ClinicalTrials.gov. Results were uploaded to Rayyan. Each article was independently and blindly assessed by two reviewers. A third reviewer blindly resolved any discrepancies. Data were then independently extracted by the two reviewers. Discrepancies were flagged and resolved collaboratively.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Results indicate that barbershop-based health-promotion efforts that prioritize community engagement and intentional alignment to the gender- and race-based lived experiences of Black men are likely to result in satisfactory recruitment, retention, and health-related changes among these men.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">More intervention efforts are needed that target young Black adults, rural Black men, mental health outcomes, and which implement peer-to-peer models. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Wippold</LastName><ForeName>Guillermo M</ForeName><Initials>GM</Initials><Identifier Source="ORCID">0000-0002-0095-298X</Identifier><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, University of South Carolina.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Frary</LastName><ForeName>Sarah Grace</ForeName><Initials>SG</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, University of South Carolina.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Garcia</LastName><ForeName>Kaylyn A</ForeName><Initials>KA</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, University of South Carolina.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList><ArticleDate DateType="Electronic"><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>25</Day></ArticleDate></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>Health Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>8211523</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0278-6133</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo><CitationSubset>IM</CitationSubset><MeshHeadingList><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D000328" MajorTopicYN="N">Adult</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D006801" MajorTopicYN="N">Humans</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D008297" MajorTopicYN="N">Male</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D001741" MajorTopicYN="Y">Black or African American</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D006293" MajorTopicYN="Y">Health Promotion</DescriptorName><QualifierName UI="Q000379" MajorTopicYN="N">methods</QualifierName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D011795" MajorTopicYN="N">Surveys and Questionnaires</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D014481" MajorTopicYN="N" Type="Geographic">United States</DescriptorName></MeshHeading><MeshHeading><DescriptorName UI="D001461" MajorTopicYN="Y">Barbering</DescriptorName></MeshHeading></MeshHeadingList><OtherAbstract Type="Publisher" Language="spa"><AbstractText Label="OBJEVO:">Los esfuerzos de promoci&#xf3;n de la salud entre los hombres negros en los Estados Unidos se han visto limitados en su capacidad para reclutar, retener y producir cambios significavos relacionados con la salud. Estas dificultades han llevado a que se haga referencia a los hombres negros como una poblaci&#xf3;n &#x201c;dicil de alcanzar&#x201d;- una designaci&#xf3;n que culpa indebidamente a estos hombres en contraposici&#xf3;n a las estrategias de difusi&#xf3;n e implementaci&#xf3;n que ulizan los especialistas en promoci&#xf3;n de la salud. Es probable que las estrategias basadas en el g&#xe9;nero y la raza que se alinean con las experiencias vividas por estos hombres eludan estos desaos. Las barber&#xed;as son instuciones culturales para muchos hombres negros y est&#xe1;n en una posici&#xf3;n &#xfa;nica para promover la salud entre estos hombres. Hay poca orientaci&#xf3;n sobre c&#xf3;mo desarrollar, implementar y evaluar los esfuerzos basados en la barber&#xed;a. Esta revisi&#xf3;n de alcance busca proporcionar esta gu&#xed;a aplicando el marco RE-AIM (Alcance, eficacia, adopci&#xf3;n, implementaci&#xf3;n y mantenimiento) para analizar los esfuerzos de intervenci&#xf3;n existentes.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="M&#xc9;TODOS:">La informaci&#xf3;n se idenfic&#xf3; mediante b&#xfa;squedas en las siguientes bases de datos bibliogr&#xe1;ficas: PubMed, EMBASE PsycINFO, CINAHL y Web of Science. Se realiz&#xf3; una b&#xfa;squeda de literatura gris ulizando Web of Science y ClinicalTrials.gov. Los resultados se cargaron en Rayyan (es decir, un programa basado en la web para la selecci&#xf3;n de arculos y manuscritos que permite la toma de decisiones en colaboraci&#xf3;n). Cada arculo fue evaluado de forma independiente y ciega por dos revisores. Un tercer revisor resolvi&#xf3; de forma ciega cualquier discrepancia. Luego, los dos revisores extrajeron los datos de forma independiente. Las discrepancias se marcaron y resolvieron en colaboraci&#xf3;n.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTADOS:">Los resultados indican que los esfuerzos de promoci&#xf3;n de la salud basados en la barber&#xed;a que priorizan la parcipaci&#xf3;n comunitaria y la alineaci&#xf3;n intencional con las experiencias vividas basadas en el g&#xe9;nero y la raza de los hombres negros probablemente resulten en un reclutamiento sasfactorio, retenci&#xf3;n y cambios relacionados con la salud entre estos hombres.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONES:">Se necesitan m&#xe1;s esfuerzos de intervenci&#xf3;n dirigidos a adultos j&#xf3;venes negros, hombres negros rurales, resultados de salud mental y que implementen modelos de igual a igual.</AbstractText></OtherAbstract></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pmc-release"><Year>2024</Year><Month>7</Month><Day>1</Day></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2023</Year><Month>6</Month><Day>22</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>42</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>25</Day><Hour>19</Hour><Minute>12</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2023</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>25</Day><Hour>12</Hour><Minute>43</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">37227823</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS1897020</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC10330434</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1037/hea0001294</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pii">2023-75205-001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Abshire DA, Wippold GM, Wilson DK, Pinto BM, Probst JC, &amp; Hardin JW (2021). Peer-to-peer health promotion interventions among African American men: a scoping review protocol. Systematic Reviews, 10, 184. 10.1186/s13643-021-01737-y</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1186/s13643-021-01737-y</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC8218504</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">34154638</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wippold GM, Garcia KA, &amp; Frary SG (2022). The role of sense of community in improving the health-related quality of life among Black Americans. Journal of Community Psychology. 10.1002/jcop.22901</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1002/jcop.22901</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC9742166</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">35700438</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wolitski RJ, Fishbein M, Higgins DL, Rietmeijer C, Guenther-Grey CA, &amp; Johnson WD (1999). Community-level HIV intervention in 5 cities: final outcome data from the CDC AIDS Community Demonstration Projects. American Journal of Public Health, 89(3).</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC1508588</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">10076482</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Yousaf O, Grunfeld EA, &amp; Hunter MS (2015). A systematic review of the factors associated with delays in medical and psychological help-seeking among men. Health Psychol Rev, 9(2), 264&#x2013;276. 10.1080/17437199.2013.840954</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1080/17437199.2013.840954</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">26209212</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Automated"><PMID Version="1">37141019</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>08</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>08</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>May</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Effects of diagnosis threat on cognitive complaints after COVID-19.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>335</StartPage><EndPage>342</EndPage><MedlinePgn>335-342</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001286</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">The term "long-COVID" refers to the persistence of neurological symptoms after being ill with COVID-19 (e.g., headaches, fatigue, and attentional impairment). Providing information about long-COVID (i.e., "diagnosis threat") increased subjective cognitive complaints among recovered COVID-19 patients compared with those exposed to neutral information (Winter &amp; Braw, 2022). Notably, this effect was particularly prominent among more suggestible participants. Our aim in the current study was to validate these initial findings and to explore the impact of additional variables (e.g., suggestibility).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">Recovered patients (n = 270) and controls (n = 290) reported daily cognitive failures after being randomly assigned to either a diagnosis threat (exposure to an article providing information regarding long-COVID) or a control condition.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Recovered patients, but not controls, reported more cognitive failures in the diagnosis threat condition compared with the control condition. Diagnosis threat added significantly to the prediction of cognitive complaints based on relevant demographic variables and suggestibility. Diagnosis threat and suggestibility interacted (i.e., suggestible individuals were particularly vulnerable to the impact of a diagnosis threat).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Diagnosis threat may contribute to the persistence of complaints regarding cognitive impairment among recovered COVID-19 patients. Suggestibility may be an underlying mechanism that increases the impact of diagnosis threat. Other factors, such as vaccination status, may be at play though we are only at the initial stages of research concerning their impact. These may be the focus of future research, aiding in identifying risk factors for experiencing COVID-19 symptoms past the resolution of its acute phase. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Version="1">37141018</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>08</Month><Day>24</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>08</Month><Day>24</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>May</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Combined effects of cumulative stress and daily stressors on daily health.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>325</StartPage><EndPage>334</EndPage><MedlinePgn>325-334</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001281</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">It has been proposed that cumulative stress, one's experience of chronic stressors across multiple domains, worsens health by altering the extent to which daily stressors impact daily affect and physical symptoms. Recent work confirms that high cumulative stress exacerbates the association between daily stressor exposure and increased daily negative affect, though it remains untested the extent to which cumulative stress and daily stressor exposure interact to predict daily symptoms.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">We employed data from the second wave of the midlife in the U.S. Survey (N = 2,022; M<sub>age</sub> = 56.2; 57.2% female) to examine whether levels of cumulative stress compound daily symptoms on days with (vs. without) stressful events. Experiences of life stressors across eight domains, occurrence of daily stressors, and occurrence, number, and severity of daily physical symptoms were analyzed using multilevel modeling.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Greater cumulative stress and experiencing (vs. not experiencing) a daily stressor independently increased the odds of occurrence, number, and severity of daily symptoms (ps &#x2264; .016). Moreover, after adjusting for covariates (e.g., sociodemographic characteristics, chronic health conditions, percent of days with reported stressors, and health behaviors), the associations between daily stressor exposure and odds of occurrence, number, and severity of daily symptoms were potentiated as levels of cumulative stress increased (ps &#x2264; .009).</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">The negative implications of daily stressor exposure for daily health may be most pronounced in those who report higher levels of cumulative stress across multiple life domains and across time. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Haight</LastName><ForeName>Brook Lifetime traumas and mental health: The significance of cumulative adversity. Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 36(4), 360&#x2013;376. 10.2307/2137325</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.2307/2137325</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8719054</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Watkins LR, &amp; Maier SF (2000). The pain of being sick: Implications of immune-to-brain communication for understanding pain. Annual Review of Psychology, 51, 29&#x2013;57. 10.1146/annurev.psych.51.1.29</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1146/annurev.psych.51.1.29</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">10751964</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wethington E (2000). Contagion of stress. In Thye SR &amp; Lawler E (Eds.), Advances in Group Processes (Vol. 17, pp. 229&#x2013;253). Emerald Group Publishing Limited.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wheaton B (2009). The stress process as a successful paradigm. In Avison W, Aneshensel C, Schieman S, &amp; Wheaton B (Eds.), Advances in the conceptualization of the stress process (pp. 231&#x2013;252). Springer. 10.1007/978-1-4419-1021-9_13</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1007/978-1-4419-1021-9_13</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Williams DR, &amp; Slopen N (2019). Documentation of Stress Summary Measures for MIDUS 2 and Milwaukee Surveys</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wright RA, &amp; Kirby LD (2001). Effort determination of cardiovascular response: An integrative analysis with applications in social psychology. Advances in Experimental Social Psychology, 33, 255&#x2013;307. 10.1016/S0065-2601(01)80007-1</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/S0065-2601(01)80007-1</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="MEDLINE" Owner="NLM" IndexingMethod="Curated"><PMID Version="1">37141017</PMID><DateCompleted><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>23</Day></DateCompleted><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>05</Month><Day>23</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Electronic">1930-7810</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Internet"><Volume>42</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2023</Year><Month>May</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Health psychology : official journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association</Title><ISOAbbreviation>Health Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Life events and stress among young adults in weight gain prevention trial.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>314</StartPage><EndPage>324</EndPage><MedlinePgn>314-324</MedlinePgn></Pagination><ELocationID EIdType="doi" ValidYN="Y">10.1037/hea0001282</ELocationID><Abstract><AbstractText Label="OBJECTIVE" NlmCategory="OBJECTIVE">Young adults (YAs) are at high risk for weight gain and show high variability in treatment response. Life events and high perceived stress are common in YAs and could drive less favorable outcomes. The goal was to examine whether life events and stress were related to program engagement and weight outcomes in a weight gain prevention trial for YAs.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="METHOD" NlmCategory="METHODS">Secondary analysis from the Study of Novel Approaches to Weight Gain Prevention (SNAP), a randomized clinical trial (N = 599, 18-35 years, BMI 21-30 kg/m&#xb2;). Both intervention arms received 10 in-person sessions over 4 months, with long-term contact via web and SMS. Participants completed the CARDIA life events survey and Cohen Perceived Stress Scale-4 at 0 and 4 months; weight was objectively measured at 0, 4 months, and 1, 2, 3, and 4 years.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="RESULTS" NlmCategory="RESULTS">Participants who experienced more life events prior to study entry had lower session attendance (p &lt; .01) and retention (p &lt; .01), although no differences in weight outcomes were observed (p = .39). Baseline perceived stress followed a similar pattern. Participants who experienced more life events and higher perceived stress during the initial in-person program (0-4 months) appeared to experience less favorable weight outcomes long-term (p = .05 for life events, p = .04 for stress). Very few associations differed by treatment arm.</AbstractText><AbstractText Label="CONCLUSIONS" NlmCategory="CONCLUSIONS">Experiencing more life events and stress was negatively associated with program engagement and may impair long-term weight outcomes for YAs. Future work should consider identifying YAs at highest risk and tailoring interventions to better meet their needs. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>LaRose</LastName><ForeName>Jessica
